x.definition: X, the twenty-fourth letter of the English alphabet, has three sounds; a compound nonvocal sound (that of ks), as in wax; a compound vocal sound (that of gz), as in example; and, at the beginning of a word, a simple vocal sound (that of z), as in xanthic.  See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 217, 270, 271

x ray.definition: Originally, any of the rays produced when cathode rays strike upon surface of a solid (as a copper target or the wall of the vacuum tube); now defined as electromagnetic radiation with a wavelength of 0.1 to 10 nanometers. X-rays are noted for their penetration of many opaque substances, as wood and flesh, their action on photographic plates, and their fluorescent effects. They were called X rays by their discoverer, W. K. Röntgen, but were also referred to for some time as Roentgen rays. The term X-ray has become the most common designation.  They also ionize gases, but cannot be reflected, or polarized, or deflected by a magnetic field.  They are used in examining objects opaque to visible light, as for imaging bones or other structures inside the human body, and for detecting flaws in metal objects, such as in welds
To examine by means of X-rays; to irradiate with X-rays

x-rated.definition: having a rating of X; not suitable for children; broadly, obscene or sexually explicit

x-ray astronomy.definition: The branch of astronomy dealing with the study of astronomical objects which emit X-rays, and the methods used to detect such objects

x-ray tube.definition: A vacuum tube suitable for producing Roentgen rays

xanthamide.definition: An amido derivative of xanthic acid obtained as a white crystalline substance, C2H5O.CS.NH2; -- called also xanthogen amide

xanthate.definition: A salt of xanthic; a xanthogenate

xanthian.definition: Of or pertaining to Xanthus, an ancient town on Asia Minor; -- applied especially to certain marbles found near that place, and now in the British Museum

xanthic.definition: Tending toward a yellow color, or to one of those colors, green being excepted, in which yellow is a constituent, as scarlet, orange, etc
Possessing, imparting, or producing a yellow color; as, xanthic acid

xanthide.definition: A compound or derivative of xanthogen

xanthidium.definition: A genus of minute unicellular algae of the desmids. These algae have a rounded shape and are armed with glochidiate or branched aculei. Several species occur in ditches, and others are found fossil in flint or hornstone

xanthine.definition: A type of purine obtainable as a white microcrystalline powder, C5H4O2N4, present in muscle tissue, in the liver, spleen, pancreas, and other organs, and also in urine (in small quantities) and some urinary calculi, and in the juices of certain plants; -- so called because it leaves a yellow residue when evaporated to dryness with nitric acid. It is also present in guano.  Xanthine is closely related to uric acid

xanthinine.definition: A complex nitrogenous substance related to urea and uric acid, produced as a white powder; -- so called because it forms yellow salts, and because its solution forms a blue fluorescence like quinine

xanthium.definition: A genus of composite plants in which the scales of the involucre are united so as to form a kind of bur; cocklebur; clotbur

xantho-.definition: A combining form from Gr. xanqo`s yellow; as in xanthocobaltic salts. Used also adjectively in chemistry

xanthochroi.definition: A division of the Caucasian races, comprising the lighter-colored members

xanthochroic.definition: Having a yellowish or fair complexion; of or pertaining to the Xanthochroi

xanthochroid.definition: Having a yellowish or fair complexion

xanthochroism.definition: Abnormal coloration of feathers in which yellow replaces the normal color, as in certain parrots. It is commonly due to lack of the dark pigment which with yellow forms green

xanthogen.definition: The hypothetical radical supposed to be characteristic of xanthic acid

xanthogenic.definition: Producing a yellow color or compound; xanthic.  See Xanthic acid, under Xanthic

xanthoma.definition: A skin disease marked by the development or irregular yellowish patches upon the skin, especially upon the eyelids; -- called also xanthelasma

xanthomelanous.definition: Of or pertaining to the lighter division of the Melanochroi, or those races having an olive or yellow complexion and black hair

xanthophane.definition: The yellow pigment present in the inner segments of the retina in animals.  See Chromophane

xanthophyll.definition: A yellow coloring matter found in yellow autumn leaves, and also produced artificially from chlorophyll; -- formerly called also phylloxanthin

xanthopous.definition: Having a yellow stipe, or stem

xanthoproteic.definition: Pertaining to, or derived from, xanthoprotein; showing the characters of xanthoprotein; as, xanthoproteic acid; the xanthoproteic reaction for albumin

xanthoprotein.definition: A yellow acid substance formed by the action of hot nitric acid on albuminous or proteid matter. It is changed to a deep orange-yellow color by the addition of ammonia

xanthopuccine.definition: One of three alkaloids found in the root of the yellow puccoon (Hydrastis Canadensis). It is a yellow crystalline substance, and resembles berberine

xanthorhamnin.definition: A glucoside extracted from Persian berries as a yellow crystalline powder, used as a dyestuff

xanthorhiza.definition: A genus of shrubby ranunculaceous plants of North America, including only the species Xanthorhiza apiifolia, which has roots of a deep yellow color; yellowroot. The bark is intensely bitter, and is sometimes used as a tonic

xanthorhoea.definition: A genus of endogenous plants, native to Australia, having a thick, sometimes arborescent, stem, and long grasslike leaves.  See Grass tree

xanthose.definition: An orange-yellow substance found in pigment spots of certain crabs

xanthosis.definition: The yellow discoloration often observed in cancerous tumors

xanthous.definition: Yellow; specifically (Ethnol.), of or pertaining to those races of man which have yellowish, red, auburn, or brown hair

xanthoxylene.definition: A liquid hydrocarbon of the terpene series extracted from the seeds of a Japanese prickly ash (Xanthoxylum pipertium) as an aromatic oil

xanthoxylum.definition: A genus of prickly shrubs or small trees, the bark and rots of which are of a deep yellow color; prickly ash

xe.definition: The chemical symbol for the chemical element xenon, having atomic number 54; it is one of the six noble gases

xebec.definition: A small three-masted vessel, with projecting bow and stern and convex decks, used in the Mediterranean for transporting merchandise, etc.  It carries large square sails, or lateen sails, or both.  Xebecs were formerly armed and used by corsairs

xenarthra.definition: The suborder of mammals including the armadillos, American anteaters, and sloths

xenelasia.definition: A Spartan institution which prohibited strangers from residing in Sparta without permission, its object probably being to preserve the national simplicity of manners

xenicidae.definition: A natural family of birds comprising the New Zealand wrens, synonymous with Acanthisittidae

xenicus.definition: The type genus for the bird family Xenicidae

xenium.definition: A present given to a guest or stranger, or to a foreign ambassador

xenodochium.definition: A house for the reception of strangers

xenogenetic.definition: Of or pertaining to xenogenesis; as, the xenogenetic origin of microzymes

xenomania.definition: A mania for, or an inordinate attachment to, foreign customs, institutions, manners, fashions, etc

xenomi.definition: A suborder of soft-rayed fresh-water fishes of which the blackfish of Alaska (Dallia pectoralis) is the type

xenon.definition: A very heavy, inert gaseous element of the noble gas group, occurring in the atmosphere in the proportion of one volume is about 20 millions.  It was discovered by Ramsay and Travers in 1898.  It can be condensed to a liquid boiling at -107° C., and to a solid which melts at -111.9° C.  Symbol Xe (formerly also X); atomic number 54; atomic weight 131.3

xenopterygii.definition: A suborder of fishes including Gobiesox and allied genera. These fishes have soft-rayed fins, and a ventral sucker supported in front by the pectoral fins. They are destitute of scales

xenotime.definition: A native phosphate of yttrium occurring in yellowish-brown tetragonal crystals

xenyl.definition: The radical characteristic of xenylic compounds

xenylic.definition: Pertaining to, derived from, designating, certain amido compounds obtained by reducing certain nitro derivatives of diphenyl

xeraphim.definition: An old money of account in Bombay, equal to three fifths of a rupee

xeriff.definition: A gold coin formerly current in Egypt and Turkey, of the value of about  9s. 6d., or about $2.30 (ca. 1900); -- also, in Morocco, a ducat

xeronic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C8H12O4, related to fumaric acid, and obtained from citraconic acid as an oily substance having a bittersweet taste; -- so called from its tendency to form its anhydride

xerophagy.definition: Among the primitive Christians, the living on a diet of dry food in Lent and on other fasts

xerophilous.definition: Drought-loving; able withstand the absence or lack of moisture

xerophthalmia.definition: An abnormal dryness of the eyeball produced usually by long-continued inflammation and subsequent atrophy of the conjunctiva

xerophyllum.definition: A small genus of North American herbs having grasslike basal leaves: squaw grass; sometimes placed in family Melanthiaceae

xerophyte.definition: A plant adapted for life with a limited supply of water; compare hydrophyte and mesophyte

xerophytic.definition: Adapted to a xeric (or dry) environment; as, cacti are xerophytic plants; xerophytic adaptations

xerox.definition: A copying machine which copies graphic matter by the action of light on an electrically charged photoconductive insulating surface in which the latent image is developed with a resinous powder
A copy made by the xerox process
To copy a printed document on a xerographic device

xi.definition: The Roman number symbolizing the value eleven.  Used after a noun it may symbolize the ordinal number; as, Superbowl XI

xian.definition: The capital of the ancient Chinese empire

xii.definition: The Roman number symbolizing the value twelve; denoting a quantity consisting of 12 items or units.   Used after a noun it may symbolize the ordinal number; as, Superbowl XII

xiii.definition: the Roman number symbolizing the value thirteen.  Used after a noun it may symbolize the ordinal number; as, Superbowl XIII

xiphias.definition: A genus of fishes comprising the common swordfish

xiphidium.definition: A genus of plants of the order Haemodraceae, having two-ranked, sword-shaped leaves

xiphioid.definition: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a cetacean of the genus Xiphius or family Xiphiidae

xiphiplastron.definition: The posterior, or fourth, lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- called also xiphisternum

xiphisternum.definition: The posterior segment, or extremity, of the sternum; -- sometimes called metasternum, ensiform cartilage, ensiform process, or xiphoid process

xiphius.definition: A genus of cetaceans having a long, pointed, bony beak, usually two tusklike teeth in the lower jaw, but no teeth in the upper jaw

xiphodon.definition: An extinct genus of artiodactylous mammals found in the European Tertiary formations. It had slender legs, didactylous feet, and small canine teeth

xl.definition: the Roman number symbolizing the value forty

xmas.definition: Christmas; -- an abbreviation for the Christian holiday celebrating the birth of Christ; a quarter day in England, Wales, and Ireland

xp.definition: The first two letters of the Greek word CHRISTOS, Christ; -- an abbreviation used with the letters separate or, oftener, in a monogram, often inclosed in a circle, as a symbol or emblem of Christ. It use as an emblem was introduced by Constantine the Great, whence it is known as the Constantinian symbol, or monogram. See Labarum

xt.definition: An abbreviation for crosstalk, the presence of an unwanted signal via an accidental coupling

xv.definition: The Roman number symbolizing the value fifteen

xvi.definition: The Roman number symbolizing the value sixteen

xvii.definition: The Roman number symbolizing the value seventeen

xviii.definition: The Roman number symbolizing the value eighteen

xx.definition: The Roman number representing twenty; denoting a quantity consisting of 20 items or units

xxx.definition: The Roman number representing thirty; -- in the postposition, designating the thirtieth in a series

xylamide.definition: An acid amide derivative of xylic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance

xylan.definition: A gummy substance of the pentosan class, present in woody tissue, and yielding xylose on hydrolysis; wood gum

xylanthrax.definition: Wood coal, or charcoal; -- so called in distinction from mineral coal

xylaria.definition: The type genus of the natural family Xylariaceae; fungi with perithecia in the upper part of erect black woody stromata

xylariaceae.definition: A natural family of fungi characterized by dark brown to back spores

xylem.definition: That portion of a fibrovascular bundle which has developed, or will develop, into wood cells; -- distinguished from phloem

xylene.definition: Any of a group of three metameric hydrocarbons of the aromatic series, found in coal and wood tar, and so named because found in crude wood spirit. They are colorless, oily, inflammable liquids, C6H4.(CH3)2, being dimethyl benzenes, and are called respectively orthoxylene, metaxylene, and paraxylene. Called also xylol

xylenol.definition: Any one of six metameric phenol derivatives of xylene, obtained as crystalline substances, (CH3)2.C6H3.OH

xyletic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex acid related to mesitylenic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance by the action of sodium and carbon dioxide on crude xylenol

xylic.definition: Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, xylene; specifically, designating any one of several metameric acids produced by the partial oxidation of mesitylene and pseudo-cumene

xylidic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, either one of two distinct acids which are derived from xylic acid and related compounds, and are metameric with uvitic acid

xylidine.definition: Any one of six metameric hydrocarbons, (CH3)2.C6H3.NH2, resembling aniline, and related to xylene. They are liquids, or easily fusible crystalline substances, of which three are derived from metaxylene, two from orthoxylene, and one from paraxylene. They are called the amido xylenes

xylindein.definition: A green or blue pigment produced by Peziza in certain kinds of decayed wood, as the beech, oak, birch, etc., and extracted as an amorphous powder resembling indigo

xylite.definition: A liquid hydrocarbon found in crude wood spirits

xylitone.definition: A yellow oil having a geraniumlike odor, produced as a side product in making phorone; -- called also xylite oil

xylo-.definition: A combining form from Gr. xy`lon wood; as in xylogen, xylograph

xylobalsamum.definition: The dried twigs of a Syrian tree (Balsamodendron Gileadense)

xylocarpous.definition: Bearing fruit which becomes hard or woody

xylocopa.definition: A genus of hymenopterous insects including the carpenter.  See Carpenter bee, under Carpenter

xylogen.definition: Nascent wood; wood cells in a forming state

xylograph.definition: An engraving on wood, or the impression from such an engraving; a print by xylography

xylographic.definition: Of or pertaining to xylography, or wood engraving

xylography.definition: The art of engraving on wood
The art of making prints from the natural grain of wood
A method pf printing in colors upon wood for purposes of house decoration

xyloid.definition: Resembling wood; having the nature of wood

xyloidin.definition: A substance resembling pyroxylin, obtained by the action of nitric acid on starch; -- called also nitramidin

xylology.definition: The branch of dendrology treating of the gross and minute structure of wood

xylophaga.definition: A genus of marine bivalves which bore holes in wood.  They are allied to Pholas

xylophagan.definition: One of a tribe of beetles whose larvae bore or live in wood

xylophagides.definition: A tribe or family of dipterous flies whose larvae live in decayed wood. Some of the tropical species are very large

xylophagous.definition: Eating, boring in, or destroying, wood; -- said especially of certain insect larvae, crustaceans, and mollusks

xylophilan.definition: One of a tribe of beetles (Xylophili) whose larvae live on decayed wood

xylophilous.definition: Of or pertaining to the xylophilans

xylophone.definition: Originally, an instrument common among the Russians, Poles, and Tartars, consisting of a series of strips of wood or glass graduated in length to the musical scale, resting on belts of straw, and struck with two small hammers; now any similar musical instrument composed of a series of bars of graduated length.  Called in Germany strohfiedel, or straw fiddle
An instrument to determine the vibrative properties of different kinds of wood

xyloplastic.definition: Formed of wood pulp by molds; relating to casts made of wood pulp in molds

xylopyrography.definition: The art or practice of burning pictures on wood with a hot iron; -- called also wood burning and poker painting.  See Poker picture, under Poker

xyloquinone.definition: Any one of a group of quinone compounds obtained respectively by the oxidation of certain xylidine compounds. In general they are yellow crystalline substances

xylorcin.definition: A derivative of xylene obtained as a white crystalline substance which on exposure in the air becomes red; -- called also betaorcin

xylose.definition: An unfermentable sugar of the pentose class, C5H10O5, formed by the hydrolysis of xylan; wood sugar

xylostein.definition: A glucoside found in the poisonous berries of a species of honeysuckle (Lonicera xylosteum), and extracted as a bitter, white, crystalline substance

xylotomist.definition: One versed or engaged in xylotomy

xylotomous.definition: Capable of boring or cutting wood; -- said of many insects

xylotomy.definition: Art of preparing sections (transverse, tangential, or radial) of wood, esp. by means of a microtome, for microscopic examination

xylotrya.definition: A genus of marine bivalves closely allied to Teredo, and equally destructive to timber. One species (Xylotrya fimbriata) is very common on the Atlantic coast of the United States

xylyl.definition: Any one of three metameric radicals which are characteristic respectively of the three xylenes

xylylene.definition: Any one of three metameric radicals, CH2.C6H4.CH2, derived respectively from the three xylenes. Often used adjectively; as, xylylene alcohol

xyridaceous.definition: Of or pertaining to a natural order (Xyrideae) of endogenous plants, of which Xyris is the type

xyris.definition: A genus of endogenous herbs with grassy leaves and small yellow flowers in short, scaly-bracted spikes; yellow-eyed grass. There are about seventeen species in the Atlantic United States

xyst.definition: A long and open portico, for athletic exercises, as wrestling, running, etc., for use in winter or in stormy weather

xystarch.definition: An officer having the superintendence of the xyst
